official-title.#text:
To designate the Rachel Carson Nature Trail, and for
		  other purposes.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Rachel Carson Nature Trail Designation
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

was born on May
			 27, 1907, on a farm in Springdale, Pennsylvania, graduated magna cum laude with
			 a bachelor’s degree in biology from the Pennsylvania College for Women (later
			 Chatham College), and was awarded a full scholarship that enabled her to obtain
			 a master’s degree in marine zoology from Johns Hopkins University in
			 Baltimore;

was a
			 world-renowned environmental scientist, writer, and educator;

worked as a
			 writer, editor, and ultimately Editor-in-Chief for the

published the
			 groundbreaking book Silent Spring in September 1962, which was translated into
			 more than a dozen foreign languages and inspired the environmental
			 movement;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
Glover Archbold Park in the District of Columbia for her
			 observations and study of nature and the environment;

text.#text:
accomplished much
			 of her professional work at the United States

performed research
			 on pesticides, the findings of which were sustained by a Science Advisory
			 Committee appointed during President John F. Kennedy’s administration, and
			 resulted in State legislatures enacting pesticide-regulating
			 legislation;

was inducted into
			 the American Academy of Arts and Letters and received many other honors;

passed away on
			 April 14, 1964, in Silver Spring, Maryland; and

leaves a rich
			 legacy that will continue to benefit present and future generations well beyond
			 the 50th anniversary of Silent Spring in September 2012.

header.#text:
Designation of
			 the Rachel Carson Trail

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
as Reservation 351 and 450, shall be designated and
			 known as the

text.#text:
The trail located in Glover Archbold Park
			 in the District of Columbia from Canal Road to Van Ness Street, designated by
			 the

is
			 deemed to be a reference to the

text.#text:
Any
			 reference in any law, regulations, document, record, map, paper, or other
			 record of the United States to the trail referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall post signs on or near the Rachel Carson Nature
			 Trail that include one or more of the following:

text.#text:
Information on
			 Rachel Carson and her contributions to the environmental movement.

References to
			 Rachel Carson’s efforts to educate others about the importance of environmental
			 protection, conservation, and sustainability.
